column2: The realm's nobles have high autonomy. They can make almost all decisions without the consent of the central authority.
The realm's nobles have average autonomy. They can make many decisions without the consent of the central authority.
The realm's nobles have little autonomy. Any decisions outside the day-to-day running of their fiefs needs to be run through the central authority.
Almost all armed forces are raised by the nobles. There is no to little of a standing army beyond the household guards and personal retinue of the ruler and his court.
Some of the armed forces are raised by the nobles. There is a central standing army which can be supplemented by levies raised by the nobility
Few of the armed forces are raised by the nobles. The central standing army is large enough that levies are not needed for army supplement.
The nobility, in return for their loyalty, are completely excempt from taxes.
The nobility pay a tax, but it is a portion of what the rest of the population pays.
There is no special tax reduction for the nobility. They pay the same taxes as the rest of the population.
The nobility is allowed to knight anyone they please for any reason. There are no restictions whatsoever.
The nobility is allowed to knight people under specific conditions for a small number of tasks. All other knightings must be given out by the central authority.
The nobility is not allowed to knight people. All knightings must go through the central authority.
About 5% of all land in the realm is controlled by the central authority instead of the nobles.
About 10% of all land in the realm is controlled by the central authority instead of the nobles.
About 30% of all land in the realm is controlled by the central authority instead of the nobles.
About 50% of all land in the realm is controlled by the central authority instead of the nobles.
About 70% of all land in the realm is controlled by the central authority instead of the nobles.
Nearly all of the land in the realm is controlled by the central authority.
Serfdom is enforced. Serfs are bound to the land they work unless they are specifically granted leave or property by their master

Serfdom is legal but discouraged. The rulers want to bring the realm on the way towards abolishing serfdom, be it because of the aspirations of their own or because of practical reasons. Serfdom appears to be a unliked institution that will mostly be replaced by a system of indentured servitude or through ownership of land by freeholding peasants.

Serfdom is illegal. Those who practice it are punished. Every serf in the realm has been liberated and made a free person, who is not restricted by location and can move elsewhere to improve their chances. How it applies in practice is another matter.
Slavery is allowed. Slaves are used from manual labor to various other tasks as well as grand infrastructure projects.
There are no new slaves. Any child born to a slave is free. Slavery is only maintained either through trade, or through active enslavement of other peoples.
Slavery is forbidden and punished by law.
No one is allowed to vote.
column6: A nadie se le permite votar.

column2: Only aristocrats and Capitalists may vote.
column3: Seuls les aristocrates et les capitalistes peuvent voter.
column4: Nur Aristokraten und Kapitalisten haben Wahlrecht.
column6: Solo votan los Arist?ratas y los Capitalistas.

column3: Droit de vote pond?r?bas?sur la fortune

column2: Only the wealthy (clerks and above) may vote, but the rich men's votes are worth twice as much as middle-class votes.
column3: Seuls les plus ais? (employ? ou sup?ieur) peuvent voter, mais les votes des riches comptent deux fois plus que ceux des classes moyennes.
column4: Nur wohlhabende Menschen (Angestellte und h?er) d?fen w?len, aber die Stimmen reicher M?ner z?len doppelt so viel wie die von Angeh?igen der Mittelklasse.
column6: Solo pueden votar las clases adineradas (Oficinistas y superiores), pero los votos de los ricos valen el doble que los de las clases medias.

column3: Droit de vote bas?sur la fortune

column2: Only the middle and upper classes may vote.
column3: Seules les classes moyennes et sup?ieures peuvent voter.
column4: Nur Angeh?ige der Mittel- und Oberklasse d?fen w?len.
column6: Solo pueden votar las clases altas y medias.

column3: Droit de vote universel pond?r?Universal gewichtete Wahl

column2: Everyone is allowed to vote, but the rich men's votes are worth more.
column3: Tout le monde peut voter, mais les votes des riches comptent davantage.
column4: Jedermann darf w?len, aber die Stimmen reicher M?ner z?len mehr.
column6: Todo el mundo tiene derecho al voto, pero los votos de los ricos valen m?.

column2: Only those of the primary culture can vote.
All primary and accepted cultures can vote.
All people can vote regardless of their culture.
The candidate with the most votes wins.
column3: Le candidat qui obtient le plus de voix l'emporte.
column4: Der Kandidat mit den meisten Stimmen gewinnt.
column6: Gana el candidato con m? votos.

column2: The Jefferson Method is a highest averages method for allocating seats.
column3: La m?hode de Jefferson correspond ?la m?hode des moyennes les plus hautes pour attribuer des si?es.
column4: Die Jefferson-Methode ist eine Methode der h?hsten Querschnittswerte zur Zuteilung der Sitze.
column6: El m?odo Jefferson es un m?odo de asignaci? de esca?s basado en medias superiores.

column2: The percentage of votes that groups of candidates obtain in elections equals the percentage of seats they receive
column3: Le pourcentage de voix que les groupes de candidats obtiennent lors des ?ections correspondent au pourcentage de si?es qu'ils re?ivent.
column4: Der Prozentsatz an Stimmen, den Kandidatengruppen bei Wahlen erzielen, ist gleich dem Prozentsatz an Sitzen, den sie erhalten.
column6: El porcentaje de votos obtenido por los grupos en las elecciones equivale al de esca?s que reciben.

column2: Trading rights for specific goods are for specific people only. Usually, these people are the nobles or powerful guilds.
Trading rights for specific goods are for specific people only. This only affects a couple goods rather than most.
No exclusive trading rights are granted. There are no restrictions on who can trade what.
Apprentices are determined by a person's bloodline. A son will be his father's apprentice, and the grandson will be the father's.
Apprentices can either be hereditary or appointed.
Existing guilds have schools in which students can learn their trade. From here, these students can get apprenticeships with guild members.

The monopoly on the sale of state supplies, ranging from military goods to the everyday food the court consumes, is held by the cities and the burghers alone with others being at a severe disadvantage when dealing with it. Thus the burghers and various guilds are able to leverage exorbitant prices for their products.

There are no restrictions on the sale of goods to the state and it is determined only by the demand of such and nothing else. The state employs their own suppliers to guarantee the independence from private enterprises. The monopoly on the sale however is partially transferred to the state as it tries to maintain self-sufficiency.
Most of the supplies are still bought from the burghers and the guilds, however it is possible for other sources to sell their products to the state and hindrances to it have been partially removed.
Cities are completely independent of the central authority.
Recognized cities are given a charter from the authority.
Cities are incorporated into different territorial regions.
Cities are owned directly by the central authority.
Aristocrats or capitalists have been assigned seats in the Upper House by the leader of the realm.
column3: Le dirigeant du pays a attribu?aux aristocrates ou aux capitalistes des si?es ?la Chambre haute.
column4: Aristokraten oder Kapitalisten wurden vom Anf?rer des Landes Sitze im Oberhaus zugeteilt.
column6: El l?er del pa? asigna los esca?s de la c?ara alta a Arist?ratas o Capitalistas.

column3: Chambre haute identique au parti dirigeant

column2: Only members of the ruling party with the same ideology can be appointed to represent the party in the Upper House.
column3: Seuls les membres du parti dirigeant de m?e id?logie peuvent ?re nomm? pour repr?enter le parti ?la Chambre haute.
column4: Nur Mitglieder der Regierungspartei, die derselben Ideologie anh?gen, k?nen zur Vertretung der Partei im Oberhaus ausgew?lt werden.
column6: Solo se puede nombrar a miembros del partido gobernante, con la misma ideolog?, que lo representan en la c?ara alta.
Dos esca?os por estado en la CA

column2: Each state has two votes to appoint representatives to the Upper House.
column3: Chaque ?at dispose de deux votes pour nommer les repr?entants de la Chambre haute.
column4: Jeder Staat hat zwei Stimmen zur Ernennung von Oberhausvertretern.
column6: Cada estado puede nombrar a dos representantes en la c?ara alta.

column2: Representatives are determined by the collected ideologies of the population.
column3: Les id?logies de la population d?erminent les repr?entants.
column4: Die Vertreter werden anhand der in der Bev?kerung pr?enten Ideologien bestimmt.
column6: Los representantes se determinan en funci? de las ideolog?s de la poblaci?.

column2: Petty criminals are hanged for their crimes and major offendors are decapitated.
The punishment system is expanded. For serious crimes that do not warrant death, criminals are sentenced to hard labor.
The punishment system is expanded farther. For crimes that are not serious enough to warrant hard labor, criminals are sentenced to prisons for a specific amount of time related to their crime.
Public meetings and rallies are allowed.
column3: Les r?nions publiques et les rassemblements sont autoris?.
column6: Se permiten concentraciones y reuniones p?licas.

column2: Public meetings are allowed during the day. At sundown, they are to disband or have its members arrested.

column3: Les r?nions publiques ne sont pas autoris?s.

column2: Year 2954, of the Third Age. It is a time of great sorrow for the Men of the West. In the past year, both King Fengel of Rohan and Steward Turgon have died. In TA 2951, Sauron declared his return to Mordor, started rebuilding his Dark Tower of Barad-d˚r and sent three Nazg˚l off to unknown places. In the north, Goblin raids have slowly been increasing, despite their losses in the Battle of the Five Armies. The Elves, as always, look to their own borders, caring not for the troubles of Men, and the Dwarves delve ever deeper into their mountains, too concerned about their riches to be of help. A new great Calamity is coming.
